definition:
A topological space $X$ is said to be *weakly countably compact* (or
*limit point compact*) if every infinite subset of $X$ has a limit
point.

Every countably compact space is weakly countably compact. The converse
is true in .

A metric space is weakly countably compact if and only if it is compact.

An easy example of a space $X$ that is not weakly countably compact is
any infinite set with the discrete topology. A more interesting example
is the countable complement topology on an uncountable set.
